Transparency.justification: Score = 1 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain detailed, verifiable information.

relevantSources.title: BMS Principles of Integrity
relevantSources.summary: Document outlines AI technology transparency requirements and explainable outcomes.

relevantSources.title: Science Firsthand: Predicting new possibilities in drug discovery
relevantSources.summary: Article describes predictive AI approaches in drug discovery with collaborative intelligence.

relevantSources.title: Facilitating early and continuous engagement of patient
relevantSources.summary: Paper discusses transparency around commercially sensitive information in healthcare.

Transparency.findings: Bristol-Myers Squibb provides concrete evidence of transparency in AI practices, including explicit requirements for transparency in supplier and internal AI technologies, and public communication about AI/ML applications in R&D. These sources detail how transparency is embedded in both policy and operational contexts.

Fairness & Bias Mitigation.justification: Score = 1 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain detailed, verifiable information.

relevantSources.title: BRISTOL MYERS SQUIBB TERMS AND CONDITIONS
relevantSources.summary: Contract terms requiring AI fairness evaluations and bias assessments from suppliers.

relevantSources.title: Leveraging AI to enhance workplace innovation & efficiency
relevantSources.summary: Article emphasizes ethical, accurate, bias-free AI implementation across organization.

relevantSources.title: Building a Better Future: Bristol Myers Squibb 2023 ESG Report
relevantSources.summary: ESG report details diversity initiatives and responsible AI principles established.

Fairness & Bias Mitigation.findings: The company demonstrates concrete steps toward fairness and bias mitigation, including supplier contract requirements for bias assessments, organizational commitments to bias-free AI, and formal responsible AI principles outlined in their ESG report. These sources collectively show a structured approach to mitigating bias in AI systems.

Explainability.justification: Score = 1 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain detailed, verifiable information.

relevantSources.title: Job Details - Bristol Myers Squibb
relevantSources.summary: Job posting requiring model explainability alignment with discovery workflows.

relevantSources.title: BRISTOL MYERS SQUIBB TERMS AND CONDITIONS
relevantSources.summary: Supplier contract mandating transparent and explainable AI outcomes upon request.

relevantSources.title: Bristol Myers Squibb: Accelerate Drug Development Through Machine Learning Image Classification
relevantSources.summary: AWS webinar showcasing explainable AI approach in protein crystal classification.

Explainability.findings: BMS provides concrete evidence of explainability in AI, including job roles requiring explainable models, supplier contracts mandating explainable outcomes, and public demonstrations of interpretable machine learning methods. These sources reflect a commitment to both internal and external explainability standards.

Human Oversight & Accountability.justification: Score = 1 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain detailed, verifiable information.

relevantSources.title: BMS GLOBAL EMPLOYEE PRIVACY NOTICE
relevantSources.summary: Policy states BMS doesn't use AI for employment decisions without human awareness.

relevantSources.title: BRISTOL MYERS SQUIBB TERMS AND CONDITIONS
relevantSources.summary: Contract requires human oversight for AI systems where legally mandated.

relevantSources.title: BMY 2025 Proxy - BMS Annual Report
relevantSources.summary: Proxy statement outlines Board oversight and governance model for technology initiatives.

Human Oversight & Accountability.findings: Bristol-Myers Squibb demonstrates concrete evidence of human oversight and accountability through employee policies, supplier contracts, and governance structures. These documents specify human involvement in AI decisions and oversight by the Board for technology initiatives.

Privacy & Security.justification: Score = 1 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain detailed, verifiable information.

relevantSources.title: BMS Principles of Integrity
relevantSources.summary: Document requires AI privacy protection and personal information respect.

relevantSources.title: BMS GLOBAL EMPLOYEE PRIVACY NOTICE
relevantSources.summary: Privacy notice addresses AI data processing and employee notification requirements.

relevantSources.title: Standards of Business Conduct and Ethics for Third Parties
relevantSources.summary: Third-party standards mandate responsible AI use with privacy protection.

Privacy & Security.findings: BMS offers concrete evidence of privacy and security in AI, including policy documents that require privacy protection, address AI data processing, and mandate responsible AI use by third parties. These practices are embedded in both internal and supplier-facing documents.

relevantSources.title: BMS-JPM-2025-presentation.pdf
relevantSources.summary: Investor presentation mentions establishing principles for responsible artificial intelligence governance.

relevantSources.title: Leveraging AI to enhance workplace innovation & efficiency

Governance & Accountability.findings: BMS provides concrete governance and accountability evidence, including investor presentations, ESG reports, and public articles that describe governance structures, oversight councils, and responsible AI principles. These sources show a formalized approach to AI governance at multiple organizational levels.

summary.overallFindings: Bristol-Myers Squibb demonstrates robust responsible AI practices across transparency, fairness, explainability, human oversight, privacy, and governance, with strong policy and operational evidence in each area. The company integrates responsible AI requirements into supplier contracts, internal roles, and public communications. However, there is no public evidence of external audits or formal public commitments to external AI standards. Overall, BMS exhibits a comprehensive and mature approach to responsible AI governance, with the exception of public-facing external validation.
